news.description: New paper at UIST 2018! Ply: A Visual Web Inspector for Learning from Professional Webpages significantly extends our previous work on visual regression pruning.
I'm joining Khan Academy Early Product Development full-time after graduation!
Spoke at the Northwestern Big Ideas Forum, "How We Learn About Learning," with professors Nell O'Rourke and David Uttal, and fellow undergrad Gabby Ashenafi.
Ply wins the CHI 2017 Student Research Competition! Northwestern Engineering has a nice write-up about the whole thing.
Received a Microsoft Tuition Scholarship for 2017-18.
Ply: Visual Regression Pruning for Web Design Source Inspection is accepted to the CHI 2017 SRC.

projects.title: Ply: Visual web inspection
projects.description: CSS is syntactically straightforward, but has a steep learning curve and complicated semantics. Inspecting the source of existing webpages can help illustrate concepts, but such webpages are typically too complex to serve as useful learning materials. Drawing inspiration from prior research in both software engineering and the learning sciences, we present a new web inspection tool capable of pruning irrelevant CSS and identifying implicit dependencies between properties. Supervised by Haoqi Zhang and Nell O'Rourke. UIST 2018, Berlin, Germany.

projects.title: Evaluating peer graders
projects.description: Most of the literature on peer grading focuses on inferring a true grade from a set of noisy reports. We study a different problem: inferring the skill and effort of reviewers, from the same reports. Supervised by Jason Hartline.

projects.title: Tracing WebAssembly function calls
projects.description: With Meg Grasse and mentorship from Nick Fitzgerald and Jim Blandy, we developed a proof-of-concept tool for instrumenting WebAssembly binaries written in Rust to log function calls at runtime.

projects.title: Classroom exercise reports
projects.description: I developed new exercise reports to help teachers visualize student progress and work through problems in the classroom. Mentored by John Resig during my internship at Khan Academy.

projects.title: Visual regression pruning
projects.description: We introduce a visual significance heuristic for removing irrelevant CSS source code during web design reverse-engineering tasks. CHI 2017 Student Research Competition Winner, Denver, Colorado.

projects.title: Guiding Web Inspection with Tutorial Keyword Frequency
projects.description: In order to bridge the gap between web design tutorials and real-world examples, we extend a web inspector to highlight CSS properties frequently mentioned across a given set of tutorials. Google Scholars' Retreat 2016, Mountain View, California.

projects.title: SVG Charting Library
projects.description: An opinionated Ember.js addon to replace Highcharts with native SVG and DOM APIs. Released addon as a company-wide multiproduct. I worked on this project during my internship at LinkedIn, under the mentorship of Cody Coats and Michail Yasonik.

projects.title: Predicting the Popularity of User-Generated Discussion Questions
projects.description: Using Python with the Reddit API and NLTK library, we collect information about AskReddit posts over a two-week period to analyze what makes a question popular. Alternating decision trees achieve 72.9819 accuracy with 10-fold cross-validation, an improvement over the ZeroR baseline of 51.0708. Features related to the language of the question, time and day of posting, and initial commenting behavior prove most informative. With Sameer Srivastava, Jennie Werner, and Aiqi Liu.

projects.title: Commentator
projects.description: End-to-end Google Apps Script-based pipeline for publishing practice debate comments to individual students' feedback pages. Previously, instructors needed to manually edit the feedback pages for all four students in order to provide feedback from practice rounds. Deployed at the 2015 Northwestern Debate Institute and subsequently adopted for the entire program in 2016.

teaching.title: EECS 396: Software Construction
teaching.description: Software engineering project-based course with an emphasis on codewalks inspired by art crits. With Robby Findler and Christos Dimoulas.

teaching.title: EECS 474: Probabilistic Graphical Models
teaching.description: Graduate-level Bayesian and Markov network representation, inference, and learning. With Doug Downey.

teaching.title: EECS 111: Fundamentals of Computer Programming I
teaching.description: Functional programming using the Racket Student Languages, vacillating between How to Design Programs and SICP. With Ian Horswill and Sara Sood.

teaching.title: EECS 214: Data Structures and Data Management
teaching.description: Data structures and algorithms in C#. With Ian Horswill.

links.title: Spring 2016 Recursive DFS vs. In-Memory Stack
